comments:
FNCE 100 provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include: 1) the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; 2) uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; 3) security market efficiency; 4) optimal capital structure, and 5) dividend policy decisions.

Students as a whole agreed that this course was one of the best in the Wharton core courses. They found it interesting and “very relevant for business students.” While most were extremely satisfied with the content of the course, some suggested that “incorporating more current issues” would make it more interesting.

Students heaped praises on Professor MacKinlay. The overwhelming response was that Professor MacKinlay was “extremely knowledgeable and able to answer students’ questions without being condescending.” He also “made himself very available for office hours.” Students also liked that he used the chalkboard because it made his lecture more interactive, but some felt that the need to scribble notes quickly detracted from their learning experience.

Most students agreed that this course is one in which it is easy to do well – “tests were very straightforward and predictable” although some cautioned that “everyone tends to do very well” and the system might be better if Professor MacKinlay made his tests less predictable.

The overwhelming response was that Professor MacKinlay was “extremely knowledgeable and able to answer students’ questions without being condescending.” He also “made himself very available for office hours.” Students also liked that he used the chalkboard because it made his lecture more interactive, but some felt that the need to scribble notes quickly detracted from their learning experience.

Most students agreed that this course is one in which it is easy to do well – “tests were very straightforward and predictable” although some cautioned that “everyone tends to do very well” and the system might be better if Professor MacKinlay made his tests less predictable.

FNCE 100 provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include: 1) the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; 2) uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; 3) security market efficiency; 4) optimal capital structure, and 5) dividend policy decisions.

The majority of the students enjoyed this course. They felt that it was interesting and “necessary for business students to have a firm foundation in finance.”

Students, for the most part, were satisfied with Professor Jaffe. They agreed that he was “very intelligent and thorough” in his lectures. Some, however, claimed that he “basically taught from the textbook that he wrote” and did not find his lectures helpful. There was also a “slight disconnect between what was taught in class and the tests.”

As far as difficulty is concerned, no one felt that this course was too hard. Some students said that though the material in class was very theoretical, the exams were made up of real-life questions for which made it somewhat hard to prepare.

The main topics include: 1) the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; 2) uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; 3) security market efficiency; 4) optimal capital structure, and 5) dividend policy decisions.

The majority of the students enjoyed this course. They felt that it was interesting and “necessary for business students to have a firm foundation in finance.”

Students, for the most part, were satisfied with Professor Jaffe. They agreed that he was “very intelligent and thorough” in his lectures. Some, however, claimed that he “basically taught from the textbook that he wrote” and did not find his lectures helpful. There was also a “slight disconnect between what was taught in class and the tests.”

As far as difficulty is concerned, no one felt that this course was too hard. Some students said that though the material in class was very theoretical, the exams were made up of real-life questions for which made it somewhat hard to prepare.

FNCE 100 provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include: 1) the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; 2) uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; 3) security market efficiency; 4) optimal capital structure, and 5) dividend policy decisions.

Overall, a majority of the students found this course interesting and engaging. Some even said that they thought the “honors sections should be open to more students” so that more people can enjoy this course.

Professor Wachter received great reviews from her students. Everyone agreed that she was an “extremely well organized professor with extensive knowledge about the course.” She utilized the blackboard a great deal which made the “learning experience more engaging.” Her “example-driven approach made learning the concepts a lot easier.” Professor Wachter also made herself very available outside of the classroom.

Students felt that this course was fairly easy. Problem sets were due almost every week, but they were “not stressful and really helped reinforced class concepts.” However, students thought that “the textbook was extremely useless in the honors section.”
